lessons.title: Welcome to OOP!
masteryOutcomes: Understand the course main topics and grading

lessons.title: What is OOP and why do we need it?
masteryOutcomes: Understand why different programming paradigms exist.
Identify Object-Oriented Programming as a paradigm
Understand why Object-Oriented Programming is used based on real-world examples

lessons.title: Objects = data + behavior
masteryOutcomes: Identify an object as an entity that combines data attributes (state) and behavior (actions).
Distinguish between the state and behavior of real-world objects.

lessons.title: Classes and instances
masteryOutcomes: Identify a class as a blueprint that defines shared structure and behavior.
Understand what a class instance is and that multiple instances can be created from the same class.
Recognize basic CaptialCase convention for Class names.

lessons.title: Object identity vs equality
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish between two variables pointing to the same object and two objects having the same value.
Explain why identity vs equality matters when working with object state.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Cafe items as objects
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Model simple real-world items as objects by separating their state (data) and behavior (actions). Output: A script that prints information about cafe menu items and simulates simple actions like “serve” or “discount” using object-like structures.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Library books identity vs equality
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Differentiate between object identity and equality by comparing multiple “book” records that may share the same data but not the same identity. Output: A script that creates several book variables and prints whether they are the same object or just have the same values.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Music playlist classes and instances
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Recognize a class as a blueprint and create multiple instances to represent different songs in a playlist. Output: A script that defines a Song class and prints details for several Song instances to show they share structure but hold different data.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: To-do tasks as objects
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Identify objects as combinations of data and behavior by designing a simple Task concept with state and actions. Output: A script that represents several to-do tasks and prints their state changes when “completed” or “postponed.”

lessons.title: Mutable vs immutable, why it matters
masteryOutcomes: Understand the necessity of mutability & immutability objects.
Identify common mutable types and common immutable types in Python.

lessons.title: Class-level basics: attributes & methods
masteryOutcomes: Identify a class attribute as shared data stored on the class.
Recognize a class method as behavior called on the class .

lessons.title: Quick detour: built-in modules
masteryOutcomes: Recognize a module as a collection of related Python code.
Use an import statement to access basic code from a built-in module.

lessons.title: Objects in action
masteryOutcomes: Recognize that calling Random() with parenthesis, creates an object (instance) from a class.
Understand that the object's actions are called and use methods on a Random object to trigger behavior and produce data.
Distinguish between the object itself, its methods, and the data produced by those methods.

lessons.title: Challenge
masteryOutcomes: Apply learned OOP concepts to complete a small challenge and summarize key takeaways

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Shopping cart mutability
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Distinguish between mutable and immutable objects by experimenting with adding, removing, and replacing items in a shopping cart scenario. Output: A script that shows how changing a list of items affects shared references while strings and numbers remain unchanged.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use class attributes and class methods to represent shared configuration for a simple game. Output: A script that defines a GameSettings class with shared difficulty and theme, then prints and updates these values through the class.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Dice roller with random module

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Import and use a built-in module to create and interact with an object, distinguishing between the object, its methods, and the data it returns. Output: A script that uses random.Random to roll virtual dice multiple times and prints the results.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Lottery picker challenge
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply mutability concepts, class-level basics, and built-in modules to design a small lottery-number generator. Output: A script that uses a Random object and possibly class-level configuration to generate and print a set of “lottery” numbers.

lessons.title: Review: thinking in objects
masteryOutcomes: Review and consolidate understanding of objects, classes, and basic OOP terminology
Reflect on how to model simple problems using objects

lessons.title: Creating your first class
masteryOutcomes: Ability to define a minimal Python class using the class keyword without providing an __init__ method.
Ability to create objects from a basic class, inspect it's type, and assign attributes to those objects after instantiation.
Ability to diffrentiate between class definition and instantiation, prefereably using comments in code

lessons.title: Creating multiple objects from one class
masteryOutcomes: Understand that each object created from a class maintains its own independent set of attribute values.
Ability to create a class from scratch, and then instantiate two more objects from it and assign different attribute values.
Ability to seperate between the variable name (the one that holds the instance) and the attributes inside an instance.

lessons.title: Methods: the role of self
masteryOutcomes: Ability to define a class method with self as the first parameter (without exploring its meaning yet).
Understand `self` as a reference to the current object, used by methods to access its data and behavior.
Create an object and call its instance methods using dot notation to trigger behavior.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Recipe card class

This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Exercise goals and desired output: Define a minimal class and create objects from it while clearly separating the class definition from instantiation. Output: A script that defines a Recipe class and then creates and prints several recipe objects with attributes assigned after creation.

lessons.title: Self param, and methods that use attributes
masteryOutcomes: Understand the meaning of the self param
Ability to write an instance method that accesses attributes via self to produce output such as printing a stored name.
Capability to reason about how changes to object attributes affect the behavior of instance methods that reference those attributes.

lessons.title: Challenge I
masteryOutcomes: Ability to compose a small Python program that defines and uses classes and objects, representing real life entities.
Capability to trace how objects created from different classes interact through method calls and attribute access in a simple application.

lessons.title: Constructors: where objects begin
masteryOutcomes: Understand the __init__ syntax, and the idea of a constructor
Recognize that __init__ runs automatically when an object is created.

lessons.title: Constructors with inputs
masteryOutcomes: Write an __init__ method that receives parameters and assigns them to attributes.
Instantiate objects by passing arguments to the constructor.
Understand that required constructor parameters must be provided.

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
masteryOutcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Challenge II
masteryOutcomes: Apply constructors and instance methods to solve a small problem end-to-end
Summarize how object state is created, read, and modified in your solution

lessons.title: Review: bringing objects to life
masteryOutcomes: Review how constructors, attributes, and methods work together to define object behavior
Identify and correct common mistakes in basic class designs

lessons.title: Many objects, one class
masteryOutcomes: Create multiple objects from the same class with identical starting state.
Modify the state of one object without affecting the others.
Compare and interpret the state of multiple objects after different method calls.

lessons.title: Reading Object State
masteryOutcomes: Read and interpret the current state of an object.
Compare the state of multiple objects and explain why their values differ.
Identify which attributes changed and which remained the same during execution.

lessons.title: Modeling relationships: one-to-one and one-to-many
masteryOutcomes: Understand how to model a one-to-many relationship using objects and attributes.
Ability to decide where a relationship should be stored.
Understand how relationships affect responsibilities and state changes.

Output: A script that assigns students to a classroom, prints enrollment details, and shows how adding/removing students changes both classroom and student state.

lessons.title: Working with lists of objects
masteryOutcomes: Iterate over a list of objects to access their data or behavior.
Call object methods while processing a collection of objects.

lessons.title: Manipulating objects in programs
masteryOutcomes: Modify object state while iterating over a list of objects.
Use object data and behavior to produce program-level results.

lessons.title: Building objects from input
masteryOutcomes: Create objects using user input inside a loop.
Store created objects in a list.

lessons.title: Who owns the state?
masteryOutcomes: Understand why putting logic in the right object improves clarity and reduces bugs.
Refactor a simple interaction by moving logic to a more appropriate class.

lessons.title: Simple invariants: what must always stay true
masteryOutcomes: Define a simple invariant for an object and add basic checks and corrections to keep state valid over time.
Explain how invariants reduce unexpected behavior in multi-step programs.

lessons.title: Challenge
masteryOutcomes: Use relationships between multiple objects to solve a small scenario
Reflect on how invariants and ownership of state affected your design

lessons.title: Review: when objects meet
masteryOutcomes: Review how objects interact through relationships and collections
Evaluate simple designs for clarity and responsibility distribution

lessons.title: Encapsulation: owning object state
masteryOutcomes: Understand the principle of encapsulation, as one of the core OOP principles
Use internal attributes to store object state.
Use getter methods to read object data instead of direct access.

lessons.title: Encapsulation: protecting object state
masteryOutcomes: Use setter methods to update object state.
Apply simple validation rules inside setters to prevent invalid state.

Exercise goals and desired output: Use relationships between multiple objects (such as `Order`, `Driver`, and `Customer`) to solve a small scenario while respecting ownership of state. Output: A script that links orders to customers and a driver, simulates a delivery flow, and prints the final status of each participant.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Study group review
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Review how objects interact through references and collections and evaluate simple designs for clarity and responsibility. Output: A script that models `StudyGroup` and `Student` objects, runs a short study session, and prints how many topics each student covered.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice encapsulation by storing user data in private-like attributes and exposing getter methods instead of direct access. Output: A script that defines a `UserProfile` with hidden internal data and prints selected information using getter methods only.

Exercise goals and desired output: Reinforce encapsulation by using setter methods with validation rules to protect and control updates to object state. Output: A script that updates `UserProfile` fields via setters, rejects invalid changes, and prints the final valid profile state.

Exercise goals and desired output: Combine relationships, encapsulation, and invariants to coordinate `Course` and `Student` objects while keeping state consistent. lessons.title: Keeping it in the family: introducing inheritance
masteryOutcomes: Understand the principle of inheritance, as one of the core OOP principles
Create a subclass that inherits attributes and methods from a parent class.
Use inherited behavior on subclass objects.

lessons.title: Inheritance: sometimes kids are not like their parents
masteryOutcomes: Override a method in a subclass to change behavior.
Predict which method implementation runs for a subclass object.

lessons.title: Composition vs inheritance: a practical decision rule
masteryOutcomes: Explain the difference between 'has-a' and 'is-a' relationships.
Choose composition when one object should contain or use another object as a part.
Choose inheritance when one object is a specialized version of another.

lessons.title: Polymorphism basics: one action, different behaviors
masteryOutcomes: Recognize polymorphism as a practical tool for simpler program logic.
Call the same method name on different object types and predict what happens.
Understand why method overriding enables different behavior under the same interface.
